title: Analyzing the relationship between gene expression and phenotype in space-flown mice using a causal inference machine learning ensemble
background: Spaceflight negatively impacts liver function in rodents and humans, with lipid dysregulation being a common phenotype. Traditional statistical methods struggle to distinguish true correlations from spurious ones in high-dimensional spaceflight data where sample sizes are limited and randomized controlled trials are logistically challenging.
objective: To identify genes robustly correlated with lipid density phenotype in space-flown mice using causal inference machine learning methods that distinguish true biological signals from spurious correlations.
methods: Causal Research and Inference Search Platform (CRISP) ensemble machine learning, using transcriptomic and histological data from NASA OSDR, with data augmentation through multiple transformations and environment string construction to exploit invariance across different data conditions.
results: CRISP identified 20 genes predictive of lipid density that were biologically relevant to NAFLD pathways, while traditional methods (DESeq2, EdgeR) and non-causal ML methods (random forest, ERM) produced less interpretable or non-significant results. Key genes included Apoc1, Apoc3, Apoe, Cyp2e1, Fasn, Scd1, and Star.
conclusion: Causal inference ML approaches can identify biologically meaningful gene-phenotype relationships in spaceflight data that traditional methods miss, providing potential biomarkers for spaceflight-induced liver dysfunction and targets for countermeasure development.

learning_notes.note: The CRISP platform uses causal inference through environment invariance, training models on data from one environment and testing on others to identify features that predict outcomes regardless of data perturbations. This approach identified 20 genes robustly correlated with lipid density where traditional methods failed.

Data augmentation through six different transformations (identity, log, square root, median ratios, centered log ratio, Box-Cox) increased the effective dataset size from 51 to 306 samples, crucial for machine learning with limited spaceflight samples and providing multiple environments for invariance testing.

CRISP identified genes including Apoc1, Apoc3, Apoe, Cyp2e1, Fasn, Scd1, and Star that were significantly enriched in cholesterol metabolism, fatty acid metabolism, and alcoholic liver disease pathways, all consistent with NAFLD progression observed in space-flown rodents.

Traditional differential expression tools performed poorly: DESeq2 found no significantly differentially expressed genes, while EdgeR found only 6 genes with unclear biological relevance. Non-causal ML methods (random forest, ERM) identified genes not related to lipid metabolism despite high accuracy.

The approach successfully handled technical batch effects from different RNA-seq library preparations by including them in environment strings, demonstrating robustness to known technical variations common across multiple spaceflight experiments and datasets.

Validation through SPOKE knowledge graph identified metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD, the new term for NAFLD) as the most significantly associated condition with the CRISP gene set, with adjusted p-value < 0.001.

The study demonstrates that spaceflight as short as 54 days can induce gene expression profiles resembling NAFLD, highlighting the rapid impact of space environment on liver metabolism and the importance of early intervention strategies for long-duration missions.
